newsitem.title: USA: EXEL expected to seek further acquisitions.
newsitem.headline: EXEL expected to seek further acquisitions.

text.p: General liability insurer EXEL Ltd said it may seek out more acquisitions after it digests GCR Holdings Ltd, which it bought Thursday for $27.00 a share, or $637 million.

EXEL's acquisition of the nearly 95.0 percent -- or 23.6 million -- GCR shares it doesn't already own will leave it with between $200 million and $300 million in excess capital, according to EXEL spokesman Gavin Arton. And in a rapidly consolidating insurance industry, the company might use that capital on more acquisitions, he said.

"After the deal we'll still have enough capital to do an acquisition or a buyback," said EXEL spokesman Gavin Arton. He also said the company would consider an expanded stock buyback, adding that the GCR acquisition, however, "will slow our buyback plan for this year, and we certainly wouldn't do a buyback in the next few months," he said.
Arton speculated that if EXEL were to make an acquisition, it would probably seek a company in the "specialty financial insurance area."
"We'd possibly consider a company that provides risk-management products, like someone who insures currency risk," Arton said. He added, however, that to date "there's nothing we've targeted."
Analysts said EXEL's chief executive, Brian O'Hara, also alluded to more acquisitions on his conference call with them today, following EXEL's GCR announcement.

"They (EXEL) have told us they may make additional acquisitions," said Cathy Seifert, an analyst at the S&P Equity Group. "On the conference call they said today's acquisition won't prevent them from making further deals."
EXEL got a bargain when it bought GCR, said analysts who follow the company. EXEL's shares closed up 3-3/8 at 43.
"I liked what I saw," said Merrill Lynch analyst Jay Cohen, who upgraded EXEL from "accumulate" to "buy" and raised his 12-month price target for the stock to between $51 and $53 a share.

Cohen said the deal would immediately add between $0.40 and $0.55 per share to EXEL's annual earnings. He and other analysts also said the acquisition allows EXEL to diversify into new areas, like catastrophe reinsurance.
Such diversification is crucial in today's insurance industry, where bigger is often better because companies can achieve economies of scale, said S&P's Cathy Seifert.

"The entire industry is in the midst of a consolidation," she said. "I think if you look at the list of insurance companies out there a year from now, there will be fewer smaller insurance companies."

Yesterday, for example, life insurer Unitrin Inc said it would buy Reliable Life Insurance Co in a stock swap transaction. The deal gives Untrin a bigger presence in Texas, one of its key states, a Unitrin spokesman said.
The spokesman, who asked not to be named, also said that for most insurers, "there's always some advantage in being large."
